A predicate that filters both the samples and the deleted objects returned by the query.  Pass
to receive all the newly added samples and recently deleted objects of the specified type.

The anchor returned by the previous anchored object query. The anchor object corresponds to the last object that was returned by the previous anchored object query. The new query returns only samples and deleted objects that are newer than that object.
Pass
to receive all the matching samples and recently deleted objects currently in the HealthKit store.

A block that the system calls after gathering the initial results. This block takes the following parameters:
A reference to the query calling this block.

An array containing the samples returned by this query, or

An array containing the deleted objects returned by this query, or
if an error occurred.

An anchor object corresponding to the last object returned by this query. Subsequent anchor queries use this value to receive new samples and deleted objects created after the query returned its initial results.
newAnchor
If an error occurs, this parameter contains an object describing the error; otherwise, it is
error
A newly initialized anchor query object.
After instantiating the query, call the
class’s

method to run it. The queries run on an anonymous background queue. As soon as the query is complete, the results handler block is executed on the same background queue (but not necessarily the same thread). Be sure to dispatch these results to the main queue before updating the user interface.
The first time you call this method, pass
as the
parameter. This method returns all matching objects currently in the HealthKit store. Additionally, save the returned anchor object and pass it to the next query.

Anchor queries can also act as long-running queries. If you assign an update handler before executing the query, the query continues to monitor the HealthKit store after gathering the initial results. The system calls the update handler on a background queue whenever a matching sample is saved to or deleted from the HealthKit store. To cancel this query, call the store’s
method.

abstract.text: Access and share health and fitness data while maintaining the user’s privacy and control.
A query that returns changes to the HealthKit store, including a snapshot of new changes and continuous monitoring as a long-running query.
Creates an anchored object query that matches any of the query descriptors you provided.
Initializes a new anchored object query.
Initializes a new anchored object query.
A type that identifies samples that contain a value from a small set of possible values.
A type that identifies samples that group multiple subsamples.
An object that represents a sample that has been deleted from the HealthKit store.
The access point for all data managed by HealthKit.
Starts executing the provided query.
Stops a long-running query.
A value indicating that the query returns all the matching samples in the HealthKit store.
A type that identifies samples that store numerical values.
An object used to identify all the samples previously returned by an anchored object query.
A HealthKit sample represents a piece of data associated with a start and end time.
An abstract superclass for all classes that identify a specific type of sample when working with the HealthKit store.
A type that identifies samples that store information about a workout.
Create and run an anchored object query.
Information about an error condition including a domain, a domain-specific error code, and application-specific information.
A definition of logical conditions for constraining a search for a fetch or for in-memory filtering.
A signed integer value type.
The return type of functions that don’t explicitly specify a return type, that is, an empty tuple `()`.
A type representing an error value that can be thrown.
